title-group.article-title: The availability of open access journals in the humanities and social sciences in China

contrib-group.aff: Medical Information Department of Xiang Ya Medical School, Central South University, China

author-notes.corresp: Dehau Hu, Medical Information Department of Xiang Ya Medical School, Central South University, 172 Tongzipo Road, Changsha, Hunan, China. Email: hudehua2000@163.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © Chartered Institute of Library and Information Professionals 2011
permissions.copyright-holder: Chartered Institute of Library and Information Professionals

abstract.p: We identified and analysed the 147 journals offering open access (OA) among the 2960 scholarly journals indexed by the Chinese National Knowledge Information (CNKI) database in the humanities and social sciences. Data were analysed concerning each journal’s organizer, discipline, publishing cycle, areas, regions or provinces covered, and first date that content was offered free of charge, together with the journal’s website construction, the way full text was accessed, and the time delay in publication. On the basis of the survey results, we identify key challenges and problems associated with OA journals in the humanities and social sciences in China, and we outline development strategies to address these issues, including actively promoting the transition of scholarly journals from print form to OA, speeding up network construction of OA journals, and enhancing the functionality of the OA journals’ websites.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: The formal concept of open access (OA), including its underlying theoretical basis and pathways for achieving it, were brought into focus in the Budapest conference addressing ‘accelerating the construction that all the papers can be read for free’ [1], and led to the founding of the Budapest Open Access Initiative (BOAI). As a result of the October 2003 ratification of the Berlin Declaration on Open Access addressing resources in the natural sciences and humanities, several organizations and individuals signed agreements supporting the BOAI and Berlin Declaration. Since then, the number of journals listed in the Directory of Open Access Journals (DOAJ) has expanded from the original 350 to 4807 as of March 2010 [2].

Although OA journals began a little later in China, they have undergone high-speed development. A total of 14 journals in China, 12 in Taiwan, and 11 in Hong Kong have been included in the DOAJ. In addition, Sciencepaper Online has brought 148 journals in natural science, 51 in engineering, 40 in medicine and health, 20 in agricultural science, and 44 in the humanities and social sciences into the catalogue, and this online presence is increasing [3]. In response to this growth in OA journals, the China Association for Science and Technology (CAST) has surveyed the current situation regarding Chinese OA journals and archives for science and technology journals [4]. However, no systematic and comprehensive research has been conducted thus far that has addressed OA journals in the humanities and social sciences. Therefore, in order to clarify the current situation with regard to OA journals in these fields in China, and to analyse the development strategies utilized by these journals and the challenges they face, we have undertaken a systematic analysis of the current state of Chinese OA journals, and have recommended relevant approaches that can be taken to encourage OA publication in China and address the problems and challenges that we have identified.

sec.title: 2.1. Survey objects
sec.p: Of the 2960 academic journals in the humanities and social sciences that are indexed in the CNKI, 398 are in the philology and humanities category, 520 in social science (A), 1050 in social science (B), and 992 in economy and management.

sec.title: 2.2. Retrieval strategy
sec.p: Google organizes the world’s information and makes it universally accessible and useful, including Chinese information. Although Google will no longer censor search results on Google.cn in 2010, the best search engine to use for this study is still Google.hk.

All the 2960 journals indexed by CNKI were searched for using Google one by one. In order to ensure precision, we decided to adopt title searching by Google and added quotation marks. For example, for China Tibetology (English edition), we searched Google using “China Tibetology”. We then browsed the top 20 results and selected the OA journal based on the standards listed in the next section. Then we entered its homepage to collect some information on the journal, such as the date that OA began, OA issues, and so on.

sec.title: 2.3. Standards for inclusion
sec.p: The following standards were adopted for our analysis.

list-item.p: Relevance of the content and journal requirements. The journal must be included in the CNKI database, be catalogued strictly according to the Chinese Library Classification, and have particular standards for evaluating various elements, including the journal introduction, submission requirements, and paper abstract.

No obstruction to website visits. The journal must own a sustainable URL (see Appendix), and readers should automatically have all the authority necessary to allow them to visit the website via the internet. The homepage should be easily accessible under normal operating conditions; if not, network jams should be considered a concern. No registration should be needed, or the access should appear to be as unrestricted as possible.

Free open access. Considering the current circumstances in China, we reduced the level of this requirement, and required access to download or read the full text of at least some portion of the journal content for free. Consideration of the range of free privileges, duration and frequency of updating requires a more comprehensive survey at a future date.
Publishing situation. The journal should be published regularly, and employ a continuous series number. The frequency of publication should be at least one issue per year.

sec.title: 2.4. Survey content
sec.p: The survey was designed to collect information from the CNKI about the journal’s organizer, when the journal was established, the publication cycle, relevant fields, and the region(s) covered, and from the OA journal’s homepage about the date that OA began, OA issues, the format of papers published, the delay time to appearance of the online version, the full-text form, the effectiveness and nature of the search function, and the online submission process.
We collected the contents of 147 OA journals, and then calculated the percentage of the above content.

sec.title: 3. Current situation regarding Chinese OA journals in the humanities and social sciences
3.1. Quantity and online system models
sec.p: As of May 2010, the CNKI had already entered 2960 journals into its catalogue, including 147 OA journals (accounting for 5 per cent of the total); all the OA journals had corresponding paper-based journals.

At the top level of classification, OA journals in China can be divided into four categories: (1) single independent online (journal has its own independent domain); (2) associated online (two or more journals share one domain); (3) sponsor-supported online (content accessible on main website of sponsoring institution); and (4) subject information network-supported online (content accessible on main website, supported by subject information company). See Table 1.

Science Paper Online includes 44 journals in the humanities and social sciences, and most of the journals finance their own OA websites. Therefore we classified them as single independent online or sponsor-supported online journals. Journals Read Online (http://www.eywedu.com/) includes nearly 300 journals, of which 17 are also included in the CNKI as associated online journals: Journal of Zhengzhou University (Philosophy and Social Sciences Edition), Journal of the Word, Guihai Tribune, Guizhou Cultural and Historical Series, Confucius Studies, Theory Front, Theory Monthly, Theory and Modernization, Relics from South, Southern Cultural Forum, Translation, Prose Poem, Stories of Cultural Relics, Free Forum of Literature, Modern Law Science, People’s Digest and China Tibetology. Some journals fit several models, such as People Digest, which is included in both PEOPLE and Journals Read Online. However, Journals Read Online has more editions, and offers the latest news; therefore we considered that it has achieved OA status.

sec.title: 3.2. Regional and discipline distribution
sec.p: Of the 147 OA journals, nearly half (68) are from Beijing (accounting for 46.3 per cent of the total), followed by Jiangsu (11 journals, or 7.5 per cent), Guangdong (7 journals, or 4.8 per cent), Hunan and Hubei (5 journals each), and Shanghai, Zhejiang, Guizhou and Jiangxi (4 journals each).

These results clearly indicate that there are major gaps in OA development between the leading areas and other regions of China. We found that formal journals in Beijing included 971 in the field of social sciences [4], accounting for more than 30 per cent of all the journals in the social sciences. Social science OA journals represented 46.3 per cent of the total number of OA journals surveyed, a much higher percentage than one would reasonably expect. The results are a clear reflection of the high speed of technological development in Beijing; nevertheless, some developed regions, such as South China and East China, also had notable numbers of OA journals. Our survey also indicated that the development of OA journals in China reflects both the Chinese economy and culture.

From Table 2, we can see that the top five disciplines were politics and legal journals (40 journals), economics (30), culture, science, education and physics (18), social science introductions/overviews (18) and literature (15).

sec.title: 3.3. Characteristics of Chinese OA full-text in the humanities and social sciences
3.3.1. Full-text availability
sec.p: Table 3 indicates that, in most cases, full-text accessibility was first offered on or after 2003 (for 121 journals, or 82.4 per cent of the 147 journals surveyed). The high point was reached in 2007, with 18.4 per cent making the full text accessible in that year, closely followed by 2005 (with 15.7 per cent becoming accessible in that year). Three of the journals offered OA from the very beginning; some others, such as The Voice of Dharma and The Culture of Buddhism, have already ceased updating their online versions.

caption.p: Timing of full-text availability of OA journals (n = 147)

sec.p: Thus we find that the development of Chinese OA journals in the humanities and social sciences made a major step forward in 2003, and the number of OA journals has increased modestly in the ensuing years, with a maximum increase of 27 in 2007.

sec.title: 3.3.2. Number of volumes published
sec.p: From Table 4 we can see that most of the OA journals have published fewer than 30 volumes in OA form, reflecting the fact that the development of OA is still in its early stages in China. However, we also found that 41 journals (27.9 per cent) have published more than 50 volumes in OA full-text.

caption.p: Numbers of volumes of OA journals (n = 147)

sec.title: 3.3.3. Availability of full-text articles at no charge (free full-text)
sec.p: On the basis of a review of the OA journals’ publication history, the number of OA volumes, and the number of free full-text articles in each volume, we calculated the overall availability of free full-text articles for each journal. The result of our analysis indicates that 125 of the 147 journals had published fewer than 2000 free full-text articles (85.0 per cent of the total number of OA articles), with 38 of the journals having fewer than 200 articles in OA form (25.9 per cent of the total). On the other hand, 22 journals included more than 2000 free full-text articles (the remaining 15.0 per cent) (Figure 1). These data indicate that, in some cases, free full-text OA is limited to only a few articles in a given issue.

caption.p: Availability of full-text articles at no charge.

sec.title: 3.3.4. Timing of online full-text delivery
sec.p: An analysis of the time delay associated with delivery of full text for 147 OA journals revealed that one journal, Business Watch Magazine, had a ‘preprint’ form that preceded the print form; 33 OA journals offered electronic editions in parallel with print editions (22.4 per cent of the total); 112 had electronic editions whose release followed that of their print edition (76.2 per cent); and 25 journals exhibited a time delay of 1 year or more after publication of the print edition. In terms of delay period, 33 of 147 OA journals (22.4 per cent) were released concurrently with their print editions; 31 journals (21.1 per cent) were delayed by one issue; 15 (10.2 per cent) were delayed by two issues; 66 (44.9 per cent) were delayed by three issues; and 1 journal (0.7 per cent) was delayed by more than three issues.

sec.title: 3.3.5. Format of full-text version
sec.p: Of the 147 journals, 108 (73.5 per cent) were available in HTML format and 27 (18.4 per cent) in PDF. HTML, a hypertext markup language, can be widely used by readers with any text editor, and it offers convenience in downloading and other functions. Twelve journals (8.2 per cent) claimed to offer both HTML and PDF formats, but the HTML versions appeared to be empty links.

sec.title: 3.4.1. Searching
sec.p: Of the 147 journals, 53 (36.1 per cent) offered some sort of searching function; 11 offered only a simple keywords search box, whereas the other 42 provided more options for searching, such as by keywords, author, title, abstract or content. Some of the 42 supported more advanced search functions, such as limits for dates and pages (for example, Acta Psychologica Sinica, Journal of Harbin University, Journal of Huizhou University and Advances in Psychological Science).

sec.title: 3.4.2. Online submission system
sec.p: Only 22 (15.0 per cent) of the 147 OA journals analysed offered an online submission system: The World and Chongqing, West Forum, Physics, Acta Psychologica Sinica, Modern Physics, Chinese Journal of Scientific and Technical Periodicals, New Technology of Library and Information Service, Journal of Yunnan Agricultural University (Social Sciences), Journal of Harbin University, Chinese Journal of Information on Traditional Chinese Medicine, Journal for Central South University (Social Science), Journal of Jiangsu Radio & Television University, Journal of Zhejiang University (Humanities and Social Sciences), Journal of Yanshan University (Philosophy and Social Sciences Edition), Journal of Education Media and Library Science, Advances in Psychological Science, Journal of Huizhou University, Journal of Beijing Forestry University (Social Sciences), Journal of Social Work, Digital Library Forum, Journal of Chongqing University (Social Science Edition) and Journal of Chongqing Institute of Technology (Social Science Edition).

sec.title: 4.1. Low level of online presence
sec.p: The low number of OA journals available in the humanities and social sciences was a notable finding from our survey: only 147 journals of the 2960 listed in the CNKI in these fields are available online, just 5 per cent of the total number of journals indexed. Among the OA journals, university journals were particularly highly represented, as were the journals included in Science paper Online (37 journals of the 44). In contrast, in the natural sciences, a survey conducted by The Current State of Scientific and Technological Journals in 2008 identified 140 OA journals as belonging to CAST as of May 2007 (15.6 per cent of 898 journals), three times the rate of online presence found in our survey.

From a regional perspective, nearly half of the humanities and social science OA journals were based in Beijing, and we saw significant regional differences in online journal availability. It appears that the development of OA journals is positively related to economic development, and a higher level of economic strength enables the expansion of OA journals. The numbers of OA journals in the political and legal fields, economics, culture, science, education and physical education, social science overviews and literature were clearly at the forefront, as compared with journals in other fields such as Marxism, Leninism, Maoism, Deng Xiao-ping Theory and languages, of which none are included in the catalogue.

In terms of the history of OA journal development in China, we found that most journals in our survey (121) became available online only in 2003 or later. Three journals that originally appeared in the form of OA journals (among them Voice of Dharma and The Culture of Buddhism) eventually either decreased their update rate or ceased updating their online versions entirely. We also found 105 journals (71.4 per cent of those surveyed) for which the number of volumes published by OA journals was less than 50. Based on these data, we conclude that, at present, the availability of OA journals and archive storage in China lag behind those of other developed nations, and at present the OA collection in China is neither comprehensive nor complete.

We also found that 85.0 per cent of the 147 journals we examined offered full-text OA for fewer than 2000 articles each, and in some cases journals offered only partial OA: that is, only a few articles from each issue could be read or downloaded, and full-text acquisition required a print journal subscription. Almost half (45.2 per cent) of the OA journals surveyed had delays of three or more issues between the appearance of the print version and the availability of the same issue online; 17 per cent had delays of more than 1 year. Thus the lack of frequent updating is a particular concern. In addition, the survey indicated that there was a notable lag in updating in the OA journals in the sponsor-supported online and subject information network-supported categories.

sec.title: 4.2. Low level of functionality
sec.p: We found that 63.9 per cent of the OA journals’ websites did not support any kind of search function, and therefore users could only obtain full-text versions by clicking the articles in the journal index. Some journals (Chinese Fishing, Soccer World, Field and Track, Basketball, Chinese Wushu, New Sports and others in the Sports Press information network-supported category) offered only e-journal downloading, making searching and reading relatively inconvenient. Furthermore, only 18 (12.2 per cent) of the OA journals offered the opportunity for online submission.

Free access for readers and required payments from authors (common characteristics of OA journals) are revolutionary innovations from the Chinese perspective. Therefore the lack of efficient and convenient submission and access methodology represents a considerable stumbling block, which also slows the development of OA; more journals in the humanities and social sciences apparently prefer to obtain their profits from paper-based publication rather than from OA. Thus there is still a long way to go before truly effective OA journals and storage become a reality in China.

sec.title: 4.3. Low popularity and awareness of OA
sec.p: One survey of Chinese readers [5] revealed the disappointing fact that 94.5 per cent of the respondents were ignorant of the existence of OA journals. Under these conditions, OA still remains an unfamiliar concept for most people in China, and in the absence of relevant information and guidance by librarians or library staff, the utilization of OA resources by most scholars does not compare in any way with that of paper-based journals, university libraries, and network databases.

This survey found that many OA journals lag far behind the CNKI and other such large databases in terms of their level of hits, and these OA journals still own high download quantity. Thus readers in China are rarely given information about these free resources, and in many cases the resources that do exist tend to lose their value because of long delays in updating online material.

sec.title: 5. Three strategies for OA journal development
5.1. Promoting timely transition to open access
sec.p: In contrast to traditional forms of journals, with their high cost, time-consuming browsing, controlled use and other disadvantages, OA journals play a positive role in scientific research communication, and in the exchange and distribution of scientific information. In addition, OA is a forward-looking concept with a promising future. Research has indicated that OA can expand a journal’s visibility abroad, increase citation frequency, boost impact factors and other standard measures, and even improve the quality of journals. In the past few years, OA journals have made great strides in developed countries, and Chinese science and technology journals should learn from these successful endeavours as they strive to promote OA in China.

However, this goal can be achieved only through government-mandated changes in management mechanisms, innovation in evaluation mechanisms, enhanced registration systems, changes in evaluation systems in research institutions, and other concerted efforts. In addition, we recommend that publishers focus more closely on the transformation of their businesses by introducing new concepts and functionalities that are compatible with OA journals, as a further means of supporting OA.

sec.title: 5.2. Speeding up network construction
sec.p: Our survey has also revealed that timely and effective construction of Chinese OA journal websites remains a fundamental challenge. Most of the OA journals in China must be considered ‘partial OA’, in that only a portion of the journals’ content is available in full-text form, or appears to be available free of charge. Some OA journals suffer from a long time delay, and can be visited for free only after a considerable lag period. Journals that are considered ‘delayed OA journals’ [6] still follow the traditional form of submission, and require a trial period before a reader can receive OA authorization.

Chinese OA journals need to devote considerable space to promoting full-text availability, in terms of increasing the number of articles in full-text form and decreasing the time delay before their appearance. With regard to the format of the online full-text version, the difference between journal formats is significant one: between the more user-friendly HTML and other formats such as e-book or images, which present notable roadblocks in terms of downloading, reading and citation.

Our analysis has shown that some websites are not completely established. Empty links still exist on some sites (such as ‘Read More’ buttons with no links), and some of the indices provide inaccurate information in their descriptions of resources for full-text acquisition. Thus it is clear that Chinese OA journals have a long way to go in terms of promoting their use, and they will gain more adherents to OA among journal publishers and readers if these faults can be corrected.

sec.title: 5.3. Enhancing the functionality of OA websites
sec.p: Chinese OA websites lack full functions for searching and submitting papers online, and they need to follow the already existing blueprints for becoming a systematic major channel for information distribution by improving their editing systems, encouraging e-publishing of issues, and providing comprehensive online services. All of these endeavours will boost the popularity of OA, expand the circulation of OA journals, increase hits, and attract more advertisers, thereby allowing them to launch a variety of value-added services [7].

Journal websites should attract readers by offering excellent content and a variety of extended services, and they should consider offering personalized services such as RSS, tag or video, voice, 3D-image documents, and other Web 2.0 applications. It is also necessary for journals to engage effectively with mobile media in order to disseminate information effectively while offering sound, individualized service. We also suggest that Chinese journals build a platform for readers, editors and authors using blogs, bulletin-board systems and the like, and take an active role in information distribution and exchange; in doing so, they will not only increase the popularity of the OA approach in China but also improve the cohesiveness, effectiveness and respectability of OA journals in the Chinese academic community.
